text: Excellent! This is prime example of how profits trump safety. Very informative. They should do one on PG&E next.

Great movie. This documentary exhibits the evils of profit over humanity. What a shame that Boeing's common sense culture of safety first, with their employees' ability to have a voice in that culture ... was overtaken by McDonnell Douglas' reckless windbags who valued greed over human lives. Those two crashes didn't just kill all the passengers and devastate their families. You can bet the rushed, obnoxious workplace atmosphere that overtook Boeing's factories deeply affected their more conscientious employees. Mind blowing that the final graphics of the movie showed Boeing still trying to deflect blame long after the Congressional hearings had come and gone. Narcissism at its best!
this was really well made and really good to watch, love it

One can document a disaster in many ways. Machinery, Workers or basic procedures but not every time the ugly side of large cooperates gets exposed. Downfall gives a precise idea about what's broken about the never ending chase behind capital or profits. This doc is a slap on the face of most multinational companies who tries to do more with less and end up making irreversible messes. In a world where systematic greed has started exerting authority while in it's death bed this clever documentary is a much needed good bye note. Excellent audio and visuals. Detailed and methodical Downfall is a wake up call.

Important and clear explanation as to why the CEO and board of Boeing are very lucky not to be behind bars and why the $2.5 billion penalty was a disgusting joke. This is the epitome of a corporate crime.

This film really sums up what really happened in this case. Because a lot of people don't understand what's really going on. I applaud The Wall Street Journal, because they dared to find out what really happened, while other media blamed the pilot's competence.

I am very surprised that a company as big as Boeing could ignore the safety of its passengers, as well as the FAA's indecisiveness in making decisions.

Yet another example of corporate greed callously disregarding human life.

I'd heavily recommend this to frequent flyers, or not recommend it all depending on their personality type. And if this doesn't make you sell your Boeing stock in disgust, I am not sure what will...
I hadn't heard about any of this and found the film very interesting and certainly an eye opener.

Competently compiled with a skillfully told narrative, this is worth a watch. Depending on who you are, it may or may not be surprising. Even if you are the latter, the exact way in which things unfold will keep your interest. The short-sighted corporate profiteering at any cost will likely leave you a mixture of sad and angry, depending on your mood.

A new documentary on Netflix showcasing the Boeing's long-run corporate conspiracy. 

This is what I want out of a documentary: lots of information delivered but broken down into small bits that a noob can understand, while being time-efficient. In just shy of an hour and a half, I completely understood the message while learned a good basic of the cause of the event. There's barely any bs from the interviewees that elongated the runtime. Everyone added something meaningful to the whole picture. 

My only small problems are that it could be a bit boring at times, and the last 15 minutes dragged a bit. 

Overall, a simple yet informative documentary that effectively demonstrated the corruptness of a mega-corporation. 9/10
Shocking facts. They make it up somehow for the families of the victims who have never seen justice. This is a must-watch eye opener.
